column2: Introduction to HTML
What you'll do
Learn the basics of web pages and the language they're written in  - HTML. (Part 1)
Hi, {{user_name}}! I know you've used the internet before - but have you ever wondered what goes into showing you all those web pages?
I was wondering that, one day, and I decided to go find out. There was a ton to learn, but now that I've done the legwork, I can pass it on to you.
Before I explain anything, let's get you looking at the guts of a web page.
The page should open for you, but if it doesn't, try running your web browser.
You can also try clicking this link: https://codepen.io/madetohack/pen/BaaNeXj?editors=1000#code-area
OK! Here we are. One half of your browser should be showing you the code that the page is written in.
The other half shows what you'd see if you found this page on the internet.
If you want the split to work a different way, you can resize your browser's window to show the Change View button on the upper right part of this webpage.
Once you can see that button, you can click it, and change the Editor Layout to a different one.
Just like computer programs, web pages are written in a kind of code - It's called HTML.
You put HTML around text, and that tells your web browser what to show, and how to show it on your screen. Not so bad, right?
In HTML, everything with < and > around it is called a tag. Tags tell the browser how to display something - text, images, whatever.
Tags usually come in pairs - an <opening tag>, and a </closing tag>, like saying start and stop.
You'll also see some text with <!-- and --> around it. Those are called comments, it's info I've put there to help explain what some of the HTML does.
Let's get our hands dirty! Find the text Hello, World! in the code part of this page, and change it - make it your name, your favorite food, whatever you like.
Awesome! You just edited a webpage! That makes you a web designer, and that's pretty cool.
Let's take it one step further. Do you see the Welcome text at the top of the page? Try finding that in the code and changing it.
That's right - it's between the <h1> tags. Nice job!
See, HTML isn't as confusing as you thought, right? Find me back in the Clubhouse, and we'll continue the adventure in a more... colorful... way!
